1.statement: Suffering and death from lack of food, shelter, and medical care are bad.

2.statement: People are dying in East Bengal from lack of food, shelter, and medical care.

3.statement: People are dying in East Bengal due to lack of food, shelter, and medical care.

4.statement: Suffering and death caused by lack of food, shelter, or medical care are bad.

7.statement: The suffering and death occurring in East Bengal are bad.

9.statement: Richer nations have the capacity to provide enough assistance to reduce further suffering in East Bengal to very small proportions.

15.statement: The suffering and death occurring in East Bengal are preventable.

35.statement: If we can prevent something bad from happening without sacrificing anything of comparable moral importance, we morally ought to do it.

36.statement: As of November 1971, Britain had given £14,750,000 in aid to Bengal.

38.statement: The total funds given (about £65,000,000) are insufficient to keep the refugees alive for one year.

39.statement: No government has provided massive aid sufficient to enable the refugees to survive for more than a few days.

41.statement: Britain's aid of £14,750,000 is far smaller than the minimum £300,000,000 India needs before the end of the year.

42.statement: At least nine million people in East Bengal were turned into destitute refugees.

43.statement: We ought morally to prevent the suffering and death occurring in East Bengal when we can do so without sacrificing anything of comparable moral importance.

44.statement: In November 1971, the suffering and death occurring in East Bengal were not inevitable.

45.statement: People have not made the necessary decisions to prevent the suffering and death in East Bengal.

46.statement: Human beings have not made the necessary decisions to prevent the suffering and death occurring in East Bengal.

47.statement: It seems obvious that assistance on the scale needed (about £300,000,000) will not be forthcoming.

48.statement: The total amount given to East Bengal relief (about £65,000,000) is less than the World Bank's minimum required assistance (£300,000,000).

49.statement: Expert observers and supervisors can direct aid to a refugee in Bengal almost as effectively as they could direct aid to someone in their own neighborhood.

50.statement: Constant poverty, a cyclone, and a civil war turned at least nine million people into destitute refugees.

51.statement: People in affluent (richer) countries ought morally to give money to prevent the suffering and death occurring in East Bengal.

52.statement: Britain's share of the nonrecoverable development costs of the Anglo-French Concorde project already exceeds £275,000,000 and is estimated to reach £440,000,000.

53.statement: Proximity (physical distance) does not lessen our moral obligation to prevent something bad from happening.

54.statement: Human beings have not made the necessary decisions and taken the necessary actions to prevent the suffering and death occurring in East Bengal.

55.statement: Britain's share of the nonrecoverable development costs of the Anglo-French Concorde project exceeds £275,000,000.

56.statement: In many parts of the world, people die from malnutrition and lack of food independent of any special emergency.

57.statement: The Bengal emergency is one of a series of major emergencies occurring in various parts of the world.

58.statement: Instant communication and swift transportation make it possible to direct aid to a refugee in Bengal almost as effectively as to someone in our own neighborhood.

59.statement: Britain's share of the nonrecoverable development costs of the Anglo-French Concorde project exceeded £275,000,000 and was expected to reach £440,000,000.

60.statement: The facts about the existence of suffering are beyond dispute.

61.statement: The British government values a supersonic transport more than thirty times as highly as the lives of the nine million refugees.

62.statement: Britain's Concorde development costs far exceed the aid it has given to the East Bengal refugees.

63.statement: Britain's spending on the Concorde project is much larger than its aid to the East Bengal refugees.

64.statement: Richer nations morally ought to provide enough assistance to reduce the suffering and death in East Bengal to very small proportions.

65.statement: Giving money to the Bengal Relief Fund is regarded as an act of charity in our society.

66.statement: The suffering and death in East Bengal continue because richer nations have the capacity to prevent them but have not made the necessary decisions to provide sufficient assistance.

67.statement: Britain's share of the Concorde project's nonrecoverable development costs exceeds the amount Britain gave in aid to the East Bengal refugees.

68.statement: The total funds given (about £65,000,000) are far less than both the estimated £464,000,000 needed to keep the refugees alive for one year and the World Bank's minimum estimate of £300,000,000 needed by India before the end of the year.

69.statement: Britain's Concorde development costs (estimated £275,000,000–£440,000,000) are much larger than its aid to the East Bengal refugees (£14,750,000).

70.statement: In our society, giving money to the Bengal Relief Fund is regarded as an act of charity rather than a moral duty.

71.statement: Without further substantial aid, people in East Bengal will continue to die from lack of food, shelter, and medical care.

72.statement: The British government values a supersonic transport (Concorde) more than thirty times as highly as it values the lives of the nine million East Bengal refugees.

73.statement: Because instant communication and swift transportation enable aid to reach distant refugees almost as effectively as local aid, distance is not a moral justification for failing to help distant sufferers.

74.statement: People in our society generally do not feel ashamed or guilty about spending money on luxuries (such as new clothes or a new car) instead of donating to famine relief.

75.statement: Donating money to relief funds can prevent people in East Bengal from starving.

76.statement: The moral point of view requires us to look beyond the interests of our own society.

77.statement: The development of instant communication and swift transportation (the 'global village') has made an important difference to our moral situation.

78.statement: Buying new clothes to look well dressed does not provide for any important need.

79.statement: The traditional distinction between duty and charity cannot be justified in its usual application to giving to famine relief.

80.statement: The way people in affluent countries respond to the Bengal crisis—treating aid as charity and failing to provide sufficient assistance—cannot be morally justified.

81.statement: The traditional distinction between duty and charity, as normally drawn (treating giving to famine relief as charity rather than obligation), cannot be justified.

82.statement: Australia's aid to East Bengal was less than one-twelfth of the cost of Sydney's new opera house.

83.statement: Some people argue that giving to private famine relief allows governments and noncontributing members of society to evade responsibility for providing aid.

84.statement: At the individual level, people have, with very few exceptions, not responded to the Bengal crisis in any significant way.

85.statement: Most people reserve moral condemnation for those who violate norms like theft, but do not condemn those who spend on luxuries instead of giving to famine relief.

86.statement: Some argue that overseas aid should be a government responsibility, and therefore individuals should not give to privately run charities.

87.statement: The traditional distinction between duty and charity cannot be maintained with respect to giving to famine relief.

88.statement: It is sometimes said that overseas aid should be a government responsibility.

89.statement: The issue of famine concerns everyone who has more money than is needed to support themselves and their dependents.

90.statement: The estimated cost of keeping the at least nine million East Bengal refugees alive for one year is £464,000,000.

91.statement: Britain has given more aid to Bengal than most countries

92.statement: We ought to give the money we would spend on nonessential new clothes to famine relief to prevent people from starving.

93.statement: If everyone in circumstances like mine gave £5 to the Bengal Relief Fund, there would be enough to provide food, shelter, and medical care for the refugees.

94.statement: We can do something about the suffering from famine, either through orthodox famine relief methods or through population control.

95.statement: Whether others have already given, or can be expected to give, is a relevant circumstance in determining an individual's obligation to donate to famine relief.

96.statement: The principle that we ought to prevent something bad from happening without sacrificing anything of comparable moral importance makes no moral distinction between being the only person who can help and being one among many in the same position.

97.statement: The moral principle that we ought to prevent something very bad when we can without sacrificing anything of comparable moral importance makes no moral distinction between cases where I am the only person who can help and cases where I am one among millions who could help.

98.statement: People's actions and what they are likely to do are greatly influenced by the actions and expectations of those around them.

99.statement: Discussion alone is not enough; we must act on the moral conclusions about preventing starvation.

111.statement: Most people are self-interested to some degree.

115.statement: Given present conditions in many parts of the world, we morally ought to be working full time to relieve great suffering from famine and similar disasters.

118.statement: The author takes Bengal as his example because it is the present concern and has been given adequate publicity.

123.statement: Private charitable giving alone is insufficient to address the famine relief needs in Bengal.

124.statement: If the principle that we ought to prevent something bad when we can without sacrificing anything of comparable moral importance were acted upon, our lives, our society, and our world would be fundamentally changed.

125.statement: The author doubts that preaching what one does not practice (campaigning without personally giving) would be very effective.

131.statement: The Bengal emergency is not unique except in its magnitude.

133.statement: If we save the Bengal refugees now, their children may face starvation in a few years' time.

137.statement: The charitable person may be praised, but a person who is not charitable is not condemned.

141.statement: After the author wrote this paper, India went to war to enable the refugees to return to their lands.

142.statement: Some people hold eccentric views that death by starvation is not, in itself, bad.

156.statement: It is difficult, perhaps impossible, to refute the view that death by starvation is not, in itself, bad.

164.statement: Because giving to the Bengal Relief Fund is regarded as charity rather than a duty, people do not feel ashamed or guilty about spending money on luxuries instead of donating to famine relief.

165.statement: Relief organizations thank donors for their generosity when they receive donations.

170.statement: If we wear ourselves out through overwork, we will be less effective than we would otherwise have been.

171.statement: By 'without sacrificing anything of comparable moral importance,' the author means without causing something else comparably bad to happen, doing something that is wrong in itself, or failing to promote some moral good comparable in significance to the bad thing prevented.

172.statement: The essay is titled 'Famine, Affluence, and Morality'.

173.statement: Organizations that collect money for relief are called "charities."

178.statement: The paradox that everyone doing as they morally ought might lead to unnecessary sacrifice arises only if contributions are made more or less simultaneously and unexpectedly.

179.statement: The author thinks it is worth risking some breakdown of compliance in moral standards to promote much higher standards if the goal is to end widespread starvation.

180.statement: Giving money to the Bengal Relief Fund (famine relief) is morally required rather than merely supererogatory when it can prevent suffering and death without sacrificing anything of comparable moral importance.

181.statement: One possible way to redraw the duty/charity distinction is to say it is good to make others as happy as possible, but not wrong not to do so.

182.statement: The author says it is beyond the scope of his argument to consider whether the traditional distinction between duty and charity should be redrawn or abolished altogether.
